CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 8 in respect of control of correspondence with the Commission and with lawyer;No violation of Art. 8 in respect of other correspondence;Violation of Art. 13
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in GPE ) and placed in detention on the basis of a extradition request from the authorities of GPE where he had been charged with embezzlement and forgery . He was extradited to GPE on CARDINAL DATE and detained in FAC on the island of GPE .

II . RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE

CARDINAL . Under LAW of the former LAW Wetboek van Strafvordering ) of GPE , as in force at the relevant time , every practising lawyer registered with ORG of GPE and GPE is competent to represent accused persons in criminal proceedings in GPE . When absolutely necessary ( “ volstrekte noodzakelijkheid ” ) other suitable persons , such as foreign lawyers , may be allowed to act as counsel .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW ( Landsbesluit – Official Bulletin of GPE ( ORG ) DATE no . CARDINAL ) and ORG CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON en ORG en de Huizen van Bewaring – Official Bulletin of GPE ( ORG ) DATE no . CARDINAL ) , which were in force at the material time , detainees were entitled to write letters on DATE and to receive letters at all times . The prison governor ensured that GPE letters , which could only be written with materials provided free of charge by the prison authorities , were posted without delay . The prison authorities also paid the costs of postage . Apart from GPE letters addressed to the Governor of GPE , the Minister of ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , the Procurator - General and the Lieutenant Governor ( gezaghebber ) , all correspondence of detainees was subject to control by the prison authorities .

CARDINAL . The Rules of Order and Discipline for Prisons and Remand Centres were replaced by a new GPE on Prisons in GPE ( PERSON ) , which entered into force on DATE . ORG ) and ORG ( PERSON ) are currently being prepared .

CARDINAL . The National Decree ( PERSON ) of DATE ( ORG DATE no . CARDINAL ) , in force at the relevant time , set up ORG . ORG was responsible for the supervision of all matters relating to penal establishments , with particular reference to the treatment of detainees and compliance with regulations . However , under the system established under LAW , detainees had no formal right of complaint .

CARDINAL . This situation changed with the entry into force of the new GPE on Prisons in GPE , which provides detainees with a limited right of complaint and by which the mandate of ORG includes supervising the execution of custodial sentences , examining detainees’ complaints and considering other grievances presented by detained persons . Under LAW of the new GPE , compensation may be granted where ORG finds a complaint to be partially or wholly well - founded .

CARDINAL . Under the system in force at the material time , problems relating to conditions of detention could also be reported to ORG . In the case of unacceptable behaviour taking place in a detention facility , FAC could order an inquiry to be carried out by ORG ( Landsrecherche ) .
CARDINAL . The first paragraph of LAW of the former Code of Criminal Procedure of GPE , in so far as relevant , provided as follows :
“ Counsel has free access to a lawfully detained suspect , can speak with him in private and exchange letters with him without others reading them , . ORG “

CARDINAL . NORP Under the second paragraph of Article CARDINAL of the former Code of Criminal Procedure of GPE , the public prosecutor or , if involved , the investigating judge ( rechter - commissaris ) may , during the preliminary criminal investigation ( voorbereidend onderzoek ) and in the interests of this investigation , order restricted contacts between a suspect and his lawyer , namely a denial of access to the suspect , non - private consultations or the withholding of correspondence and/or other documents . Such restrictions can only be ordered for a maximum DATE and , pursuant to LAW , are subject to review by ORG .
CARDINAL . The wording of LAW , which entered into force on DATE , is almost identical to Article CARDINAL of the former LAW .

CARDINAL . If no legal remedy exists under administrative law , the GPE civil courts have traditionally had competence to grant relief against the administration . This competence is based on LAW ( PERSON ORG ) , which reads :
“ Jurisdiction in civil cases involves hearing all disputes over civil rights and debt claims . ”

CARDINAL . In accordance with ORG findings in its leading judgments of DATE and DATE ( PERSON ( GPE ) DATE , p. CARDINAL , and GPE CARDINAL/CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL ) on a similar provision in GPE on ORG ) , the GPE courts permit themselves a broad interpretation of the notion of “ civil rights ” . The right claimed by a plaintiff , and not the relationship between the parties , determines the competence of the civil courts ( ORG , PERSON v. the GPE , judgment of CARDINAL DATE ) . This means that civil courts are competent to hear disputes under civil law as well as under public law , provided that the protection of a civil right is being sought .

CARDINAL . The civil courts’ competence as to the lawfulness of acts of the administration is , however , limited where a remedy offering sufficient guarantees for a fair procedure is available under statutory administrative law . Whilst in principle remaining competent , civil courts are to refrain from examining the lawfulness of an administrative act or decision against which an administrative appeal lies . Examination of the lawfulness of such an act or decision is not , however , excluded if the administrative appeal does not offer sufficient guarantees for a fair procedure .
CARDINAL . On this basis the GPE civil courts consider themselves competent to rule on the lawfulness of acts of the administration when these relate to or are directed against persons in detention .

CARDINAL . Claims against the administration submitted to the civil courts are , generally speaking , brought in the form of an action for tort ( onrechtmatige daad ) within the meaning of LAW ( Burgerlijk Wetboek ) of GPE and GPE . An act of the administration is unlawful and constitutes a tort under LAW when it is contrary to a rule of international or domestic law which seeks to protect the plaintiff ’s interests , or to the general principles of proper administration ( algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur ) , which in GPE are for the most part unwritten legal standards with which acts of the administration must comply . Where civil courts are competent , it is possible to request the court , in summary civil proceedings ( kort geding ) , to take an interim measure .

CARDINAL . The Convention , which according to the domestic courts’ case - law is directly applicable in the legal order of GPE , is frequently used by the civil courts in their examination of claims that an act of the administration is unlawful .

CARDINAL . In a decision taken on CARDINAL DATE in summary civil proceedings brought by CARDINAL inmates of GPE , ORG of ORG reviewed inter alia a claim for unlimited correspondence rights under LAW ( Rietwijk et al . v. GPE , ORG ) . It held on this claim :

“ For the time being it has not been established that the interference with the fundamental right of respect for correspondence provided by < Article CARDINAL of LAW and Articles CARDINAL of LAW > exceeds the boundaries set out in the second paragraph of LAW . The special position of detainees simply renders such interference necessary .

It has been established that the < prison > direction does not allow detainees from GPE to write CARDINAL letters per week and that , for detainees from abroad , the maximum amount has been set at DATE . It is further the rule for all detainees that they may send DATE cards per year at public expense and CARDINAL extra at their own expense .

Also in the assessment of these limitations , the special position of detainees may be taken into consideration . The circumstance that all letters , both incoming and outgoing , must be censured constitutes a ground of justification for the limitations submitted . It has been established that the director , by virtue of LAW , is empowered to limit the fundamental right in this sense . The claim is consequently rejected . ”

ORG did , however , find in favour of the detainees on a number of other claims : It ordered the defendant to allow each detainee to have visits of TIME , to cover an open sewer in the prison ’s courtyard and to ensure the availability of health care services for DATE hours per week . It further prohibited the defendant from placing detainees in a punishment cell for DATE . Such cells must anyway have daylight and a water supply .

CARDINAL . In a decision taken on DATE in summary proceedings taken by CARDINAL detainees who did not explicitly invoke the LAW , the First Instance Court of GPE set out the conditions under which a person could be held in pre - trial detention ( voorlopige hechtenis ) in the ORG Canario police cell complex . As these conditions were not met , it issued an interim measure prohibiting the defendant from keeping CARDINAL of the CARDINAL plaintiffs ( the other CARDINAL having been transferred already ) in detention in this complex . It ordered his transfer to the LOC remand centre within TIME or , if this was not possible , to release him ( PERSON and PERSON v. GPE , KG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In a decision taken on DATE in summary proceedings brought by a detainee , ORG of GPE ruled that to hold a person in custody ( inverzekeringstelling ) for DATE in a police cell – that he shared with another person – of QUANTITY without sanitary facilities and without a possibility of outdoor exercise , was contrary to LAW , and ordered the immediate release of the plaintiff ( NORP v. GPE , ORG ) .
CARDINAL . In a decision taken on DATE in summary proceedings brought by CARDINAL detainees ( PERSON v GPE , KG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , ORG of Curaçao held
“ CARDINAL . The plaintiffs ... claim against the defendant , the < GPE authorities > ,

- CARDINAL orders , described in their petition , identical to the orders already issued by ORG by judgment of DATE ( ORG CARDINAL against the < GPE authorities > at the suit of CARDINAL other plaintiffs , and which orders all concern facilities of an elementary hygienic and humanitarian nature ;
- a prohibition on imposing collective punishments in the form of a denial of visits , mail or access to the canteen ;
- a prohibition on administering corporal punishments to detainees , in particular “ circle ill - treatment ” ( kringmishandelingen ) and the “ soultrain ” ;

all of this on penalty of a default fine of CARDINAL GPE Antilles CARDINAL ( NAF ) for DATE that the < GPE authorities > violate CARDINAL of these orders or prohibitions as regards CARDINAL of the plaintiffs , with a maximum of NAF CARDINAL per plaintiff . ...

CARDINAL . < It has been > established that none of the humanitarian and sanitary facilities which the authorities of GPE had been ordered to execute , following this court ’s judgment of DATE , have materialised , so that < the plaintiffs > justly claim that the < GPE authorities > be ordered once again to do so .
CARDINAL . Indeed :

- it has not been argued nor does it appear that nutritional plans have been drawn up by a dietician , whereas ... these should have been available DATE . This is not altered by the recent activities of a dietician since these have not actually resulted in the practical introduction and implementation of menus .
- it has been argued but not shown that up to now sufficient pest control ... < by placing anti - cockroach devices in cells > has taken place ;

- the < GPE authorities > recognise that an increase in the number of visiting cells by CARDINAL has not yet taken place , and no well - founded reason for this has been given ; it is understandable that security demands render that increase laborious and time - consuming , but after DATE it should have been completed ;

- the < GPE authorities > do not deny in so many words that placements in a punishment cell take place without < a prior > hearing of the detainees concerned ; the reference to the sanctions that may be applied where the instruction to hear is not respected does not constitute rebuttal ;

- the < GPE authorities > have submitted that there is now sufficient natural light and air in the punishment cell , but this is not plausible and the court fails to see , if this was indeed the case , why < the plaintiffs > would make a claim to this end , and why , in addition , an order with a default fine could therefore harm the < GPE authorities > ;
- the < GPE authorities > have not really denied that the punishment cell is not or only partially equipped with a mattress , bedding , a table and a chair .
CARDINAL . The requested prohibition on imposing collective and corporal punishments shall also be ordered .

CARDINAL . The < GPE authorities > have not denied that collective punishments have been applied , but have pointed out an emergency situation that may occur . That it is sometimes impossible to find out who in a shared cell has committed a prosecutable offence is no justification for punishing everyone concerned ; in this way innocent people are knowingly punished , and that can never be justified .

CARDINAL . And it is further established that corporal punishments have been administered , not only on the basis of declarations made during the trial that have been hardly disputed , but also on the basis of ORG the contents of which have not been disputed . Corporal punishments are prohibited under conventional - law provisions .
CARDINAL . The claims will therefore be granted . Given the nature of the prohibition , no maximum limit shall be fixed for the default fine concerning the prohibition on corporal punishment .

CARDINAL . In this connection it is further considered that , in so far as the interests of < the plaintiffs > in granting < their claims > do not lie in offences already committed , their interests lie in the prevention thereof since the danger that these < offences > will reoccur is apparently real .
CARDINAL . The question remains whether a default fine must be attached to this ruling .

CARDINAL . The defence of the < GPE authorities > that they will voluntarily comply with judicial ruling is not credible ; the < GPE authorities > have apparently done nothing about the orders contained in the judgment of DATE . This pleads in favour of imposing default fines .

CARDINAL.CARDINAL . ... nothing has induced the < GPE authorities > to do something about the worrisome wrongs in GPE . In the entire country and GPE there is unanimous agreement that the prison by far does not comply with the norms that are internationally recognised and set out in Treaties , DATE also the < GPE authorities > through their Minister continuously recognises DATE but nothing happens .

CARDINAL . If the < GPE authorities > realise that a wide variety of measures are required to guarantee the physical security and the mental and physical health of detainees ... then they receive a judicial order and nevertheless fail to do what is urgently required of them , the question arises whether a default fine would be of any help .

CARDINAL . Nevertheless , the reason to impose a default fine is that , within the framework of the present summary proceedings , no other coercive measure is available and < the plaintiffs > can not be denied the right to try now to obtain enforcement of the orders which have been granted ... ”

ORG found in favour of the plaintiffs on all claims and set a default fine of NAF CARDINAL for DATE of failure to respect any of the orders or prohibitions to the detriment of CARDINAL of the plaintiffs up to a maximum of NAF CARDINAL per plaintiff , and a default fine of NAF CARDINAL for each time the prohibition on corporal punishment was not respected as regards any of the plaintiffs .

CARDINAL . In its Report of DATE , ORG for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman Treatment ( “ CPT ” ) on its visit to GPE from DATE , found that the conditions of detention in GPE amounted to inhuman and degrading treatment . This finding led the ORG ’s delegation to send a letter on DATE to the Minister of ORG setting out a number of urgent measures which had to be taken to improve conditions of detention there .

CARDINAL . According to this ORG , GPE regulations make no provision for the use of telephones by prisoners and that , in practice , it appeared that prisoners who are resident in the island of GPE could make calls DATE and foreign nationals once DATE . Calls were apparently limited to TIME and were monitored by prison staff . As to the visiting facilities , the ORG recommended their complete review in order to establish more open arrangements for ordinary visits .

The ORG further observed that placements in the punishment cell , with only bread and water on DATE , was current practice , and recommended that GPE take immediate steps to prohibit the placement of prisoners in punishment cells on a bread and water diet . The ORG further found that the amount of time that CARDINAL general medical practitioners spent in the prison TIME for CARDINAL prisoners DATE was inadequate .

CARDINAL . The CPT Report of DATE on its second visit to GPE from DATE , in which the ruling of DATE by ORG of Curaçao ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) is mentioned , concluded that the material conditions of detention in GPE remained unsatisfactory and the ORG called upon GPE authorities to take immediate steps to draw up a comprehensive strategy to combat violence in all its forms at FAC and that this strategy be vigorously implemented without delay . It also recommended that GPE authorities redouble their efforts in inter alia reducing the overcrowding and improving the overall state of repair of the detention areas ( including the sanitary facilities ) . The ORG further recommended that immediate steps be taken to ensure that every prisoner would be supplied with a mattress at TIME .

CARDINAL . Certain positive developments concerning ORG contacts with the outside world were noted by the ORG delegation , particularly as regards improved access to a telephone and the possibility offered to some prisoners of having supervised open visits . Nevertheless , many complaints were heard from prisoners about lengthy delays before they were granted access to a telephone and about such access often being refused arbitrarily ; complaints were also heard about the delayed distribution and/or forwarding of correspondence .

CARDINAL . The CPT Report of CARDINAL DATE on its third visit to GPE from DATE records that , as had been the case in DATE , health care staff insisted that many cases of violence went unreported and that apparently efforts to keep a precise record of cases of violence waned during DATE . The ORG also mentions an incident having occurred on DATE at GPE . The information gathered by the ORG delegation suggested that police officers had beaten prisoners who had already been brought under control ; the prisoners were naked and handcuffed behind their backs . The matter had not been immediately reported by the prison staff to their own hierarchical superiors ( the director of the prison ) or to ORG and , DATE , investigations into the conduct of the police and prison officers involved were still at an embryonic stage . It further appeared that those same police officers continued to be deployed in the prison .

CARDINAL . The ORG further noted that , by a Decree of DATE , an independent Commission was established ( “ the ORG ” ) to guarantee the physical integrity of persons deprived of their liberty and to investigate any abuse that might occur .

CARDINAL . The ORG also observed that the measures adopted to address the acute problem of unauthorised prison staff absenteeism , resulting in levels of prison officer presence on the wings being considerably lower than necessary for the proper and safe functioning of the establishment , had failed , that no target date had been set for strengthening the enforcement of those measures and that apparently no alternative policy was being considered .

CARDINAL . As regards the conditions of detention in GPE , the ORG noted the efforts made to improve the material environment , but also observed that the prison continued to suffer some degree of overcrowding , that problems in providing prisoners with adequate food at regular times and ready access to drinking water continued to persist , and that the health care services had worsened in comparison with its second visit in DATE . The ORG delegation was further told that there was a shortage of mattresses , despite the fact that budgetary means were available .

CARDINAL . In its response to the ORG report on its third visit , GPE authorities confirmed that , as to the alleged irregularities said to have taken place on DATE , a preliminary judicial investigation had commenced , in the course of which a number of witnesses were being heard by the investigating judge . The ORG was further informed that the water problem ( inadequate pressure ) had been resolved , that the arrangements for supplying meals were satisfactory and that there was no question now of a shortage of mattresses . CARDINAL . On DATE , in accordance with LAW . CARDINAL/JAZ , an ORG was established to investigate a number of elements contained in the last ORG report , including conditions of detention . ORG was presided over by PERSON , the then ORG Secretary of ORG of GPE . In the course of its activities , ORG conducted a visit to ORG .

In its report the Commission recorded that inmates at ORG , as well as the judicial authorities , had indicated that there were still cases of ill - treatment of inmates by prison guards . A complaint about this had been filed with the public prosecutor ( PERSON ) in the meantime . The judicial authorities indicated to the Commission that they had strong suspicions that ill - treatment had in fact occurred . The Commission noted that it was unclear what was being done to prevent ill - treatment . It also noted that inmates could file a written complaint to the public prosecutor through the prison director .

Inmates indicated to the Commission that there are no educational or recreational programmes for detainees , thus forcing detainees to remain idle DATE . According to the detainees , it depended on who of the prison guards were on duty whether something was done with the detainees .

The Commission observed that in the recreation rooms , which were in a good state , several activities took place such as music lessons given by an inmate . It further noted that computers could be used and that there was a possibility to play table - tennis and watch television . It noted that , for lack of staff ( CARDINAL staff member ) and means to develop activities , there was only a limited use of the workshops .

The Commission recorded that ORG had a maximum capacity of CARDINAL places which were constantly occupied . Although there were CARDINAL members of staff , in practice CARDINAL were available DATE . The reason for this considerable absenteeism was reportedly the failure to deal quickly enough with staff matters ( payment of overtime , child allowances , salary adjustments , posting allowances , maintenance costs , etc . ) . As staff had already been waiting for these matters to be dealt with for DATE , they were threatening with actions if this situation did not improve soon .

In most cells DATE each having a surface of CARDINAL ORG and designed for CARDINAL persons – furnishings such as chairs , tables and mattresses were either lacking or in bad condition , and sanitary facilities were in disrepair and dilapidated , sometimes to such an extent that inmates had to use buckets to shower and flush toilets . It recommended replacing the toilet flushes and the replacing the shower heads and taps with vandal - proof materials . The report further states that :

“ the ( natural ) ventilation is “ too ” good . During hurricanes and during certain periods of DATE , inmates must protect themselves against the strong winds ( from hurricanes ) and the humidity caused by condensation . To this end cardboard boxes are hung around the beds . ”

ORG further found the kitchen of ORG , where CARDINAL meals are prepared DATE , to be in an unacceptable state of dilapidation and disrepair , as well as freely accessible to vermin , including rats . It noted , inter alia , that for technical reasons ( the need of repair ) CARDINAL cold - storage rooms were out of use for DATE respectively , and that a much smaller cold - storage facility was being used , as a result of which only limited food supplies could be stored . This caused problems after the island had been hit by a hurricane and food was difficult to obtain . It recommended that the entire kitchen , including all the appliances , be replaced .
